awd_titl_txt: PIPP Phase I: Real-time Analytics to Monitor and Predict Emerging Plant Disease
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant disease outbreaks are increasing and threatening food security for the vulnerable in many areas of the world and in the US.  A stable, nutritious food supply is needed to both lift people out of poverty and improve health outcomes. Plant diseases cause crop losses from 20% to 30% in staple food crops. Plant diseases, both common and recently emerging, are spreading and exacerbated by climate change, transmission with global food trade networks, and emergence of new strains that may be difficult to control. This team of researchers will develop better ways to detect and predict when and where plant diseases will emerge. This research will characterize how human attitudes and social behavior of stakeholders impacts plant disease transmission and adoption of sensor, surveillance and disease prediction technologies.  The team will engage a diverse group of postdoctoral associates, graduate students and research staff through research and workshop participation and foster partnerships for a future Plant Disease Pandemic Preparedness Center.

Prediction of plant disease pandemics is unreliable due to the lack of real-time detection, surveillance, and data analytics to inform decision-making and prevent spread. This is the grand challenge that the convergence research team will tackle in this Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention (PIPP) planning grant. In order to improve pandemic prediction and tackle this grand challenge, a new set of predictive tools is needed. In the PIPP Phase I project, the multidisciplinary team will develop a pandemic prediction system called the “Plant Aid Database (PAdb)” that links pathogen detection by in-situ plant disease sensors and remote sensing of crop health, genomic surveillance, real-time spatial and temporal data analytics and climate data to develop predictive simulations of plant disease pandemics. The team plans to validate the PAdb using several model plant pathogens including novel lineages of Phytophthora infestans and the cucurbit downy mildew pathogen Pseudoperonospora cubensis. They plan to engage a broad group of stakeholders including scientists, growers, extension specialists, the USDA APHIS Plant Protection and Quarantine personnel, the Department of Homeland Security inspectors, and diagnosticians in the National Plant Diagnostic Network in a Pandemic Preparedness workshop. Differences in response and spread of pathogens and stakeholder experiences will be examined using current methods and the aid of the new PAdb.

This award is supported by the cross-directorate Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention Phase I (PIPP) program, which is jointly funded by the Directorates for Biological Sciences (BIO), Computer Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Engineering (ENG) and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Worldwide, plant pests and pathogens destroy up to 40% of total crop yields and disrupt forest ecosystems through mortality of keystone tree species. Preventing agricultural losses could reduce the estimated need for a 60% increase in food production by 2050 suggested by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. Plant disease pandemics are difficult to predict. Science innovation is needed to tackle emerging plant diseases and our interdisciplinary team of researchers is working at multiple scales from the molecular to the landscape level. Our team has developed tools for detection, surveillance and prediction of plant diseases and pests and has had an impact not only on tool development but the future of  research in plant disease epidemiology that will be used to tackle these challenges. The research our team is conducting has expanded the portfolio of detection, genomic and geospatial surveillance tools, and risk assessment options that can be used to predict the next plant disease outbreak.

Global transmission of agricultural and forest pests and pathogens is increasing due to increased international trade and travel and climate change. Pathogens that establish outside of their native range can spread locally, evolve more rapidly, and become additional sources of inoculum, accelerating the process of global transmission. Breaking the chain of transmission within and between countries remains a challenge, largely because plant pathogens may go undetected and uncontrolled for extended periods, as asymptomatic live plants continue to spread inoculum and infected plants continue to be exchanged between trading partners. The innovation needed to tackle emerging plant diseases requires interdisciplinary teams of researchers who work at multiple scales, from the molecular to the landscape level, and participatory science practices that incorporate the perspectives and knowledge of stakeholders. 

Our research team has conducted research and expanded the portfolio of plant disease detection, genomic and geospatial surveillance tools that can help us identify plant diseases, map their occurrence and determine the risk assessment of spread.  Taken together, these tools an be used to predict the next plant disease outbreak. These tools are scalable to track human and or animal outbreaks as well so our tools could be used to study and mitigate the spread of global pandemic strains.

Modified by: Jean B Ristaino
